column2: Now that you're loading images, let's get them moving and shaking!

First things first - let's get back to the p5.js code editor. You can load your previous sketch (if you saved it at http://editor.p5js.org ), or get back to where we left off: https://editor.p5js.org/madetohack/sketches/pYObWwFD
Last time, we learned how to display an animated gif from the internet, and after today, you'll be able to play and pause it!

If you look up at the top, in the preload() function that we wrote last time, we assigned names to your GIFs. We already use those names to load the GIFs, but we can also do things to GIFs while the code is running.
For example, we could play and pause the GIFs in response to something you do. Maybe… a mouse click? Let’s try that!

To react to pressing the mouse button, we need to add another function. After the final curly brace ( } ) for draw(), make a new line and type the following: function mousePressed() { (press Enter twice for 2 new lines) }
That’s the skeleton of the function done, now let’s fill it out. Between those 2 curly braces ( {} ), type gif1.pause(); I think you can guess what that does!
OK, let’s run the code! Click the mouse button, and…
Hmm. It’s not starting up after it pauses. I think I know why, though.
See, we just told gif1 to pause. We never told it to start up again! For that, we need another function. You might even say our sketch is getting quite.. functional… now :D
Our new function can go below mousePressed() - so, on the line below the final curly brace ( } ), type function mouseReleased() { (press Enter twice for 2 new lines) }
To fill out this function, you can add gif1.play(); on the empty line between the curly braces ( {} ). Now you can run your code again!
Much better, now the GIF plays and pauses when you press and release the mouse button.
Congrats! You’ve got control of the GIF now – Are you ready to move on to part 3 and fill the canvas? I think so! See you there!
